newsitem.title: USA: U.S. shuttle astronauts say goodbye to Mir crew.
newsitem.headline: U.S. shuttle astronauts say goodbye to Mir crew.

text.p: The shuttle Atlantis astronauts bid farewell to the crew of space station Mir on Sunday and closed the hatches between the two craft in preparation for their departure.

Atlantis was due to undock from Mir at 9:15 p.m. EST on Sunday (0215 GMT Monday) after five days of joint operations in which a new U.S. astronaut took up residence on Mir and more than three tons of supplies were moved between the craft.
Atlantis arrived at Mir on Tuesday to pick up U.S. astronaut John Blaha, who has been aboard the station since September, and drop off his replacement, Jerry Linenger.
The three Mir crewmen waved goodbye as the hatch connecting Atlantis and Mir was swung shut at 7:38 a.m. EST (1238 GMT).
"Goodbye, goodbye," said Linenger, at the beginning of a four-month stay on Mir. "I'll see you in the summer."
Blaha, just days from his return to earth, said on Sunday he was looking forward to being reunited with his family but he would miss the view of earth from space.

"It's just a real pleasure to look at our beautiful planet," he said. "I love working up here but ... my wife and I have been married for over 30 years and I didn't realise I would miss her as much as I did."
The shuttle and Mir crews staged a farewell for the television cameras about three hours before they said their actual goodbyes.

"Unfortunately we are saying goodbye to the excellent Atlantis crew," Mir commander Valeri Korzun said during the ceremony, which was conducted almost entirely in Russian. "We wish them a safe landing."

"We are also saying goodbye to our colleague the American astronaut John Blaha," he said. "We have had problems, but despite everything and anything we have remained friends and we have completed our tasks."
Blaha thanked his cosmonaut crewmates for their hospitality and stressed the importance of NASA's cooperative efforts with Russia.
"This programme is not only important for space exploration, but also for the relationship between the countries," he said.
At the end of the ceremony Linenger peeled off his gray shuttle shirt and playfully tossed it after the departing shuttle crew.
"I don't need that anymore," he joked as he pulled on a blue Russian space station uniform.
Linenger will perform more than 80 experiments and conduct a space walk, the first from Mir by an American.
The shuttle will return to the station in May to collect the 42-year-old astronaut and bring his replacement, Mike Foale.

Atlantis was scheduled to return to earth at Florida's Kennedy Space Centre on Wednesday. But NASA officials were considering extending the flight by one day to complete a test of an experimental space treadmill.
